page.title: Quantifiers and QP
page.introduction:
Quantifiers can show up in various places in a nominal phrase. Most languages have four sets of quantifiers:
Those meaning all or not, which modify the whole nominal phrase,
quantifiers such as some or no, which do not co-occur with any other modifers except adjectives,
other quantifiers such as many or few, and
numbers.
We’ll deal with each in turn.

Quantifiers meaning all or not seem to be a category of their own. They usually occur first (or last), in a position distinct from the other quantifiers, but in the same place as degree words like only and just (which can also acts as focus markers to be dscussed in
Focus and Topic Constructions) and words that mean the same as almost (which can also co-occur with all as in (4) below), so we will refer to them as special degree words.
We will begin with the positive forms. Look for examples in your language like the following:

radioGroup.prompt: You said that your language has classifiers which mark concord agreement throughout the nominal phrases. Do these special degree word type of quantifiers which modify the whole nominal phrase have classifiers attached to them?
radioGroup.radio: No, these elements are not marked with classifiers
Yes, these elements are marked with classifiers as part of the concord agreement throughout the nominal phrase

form.prompt: Since you have already detailed the forms of the classifiers, you only need to enter the roots for each of the words asked for on this page.

Key the way your language expresses “all", with each word on a separate line. (If “all" is an affix or a clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

Key the way your language expresses “almost", with each word on a separate line. (If “almost" is an affix or a clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

Key the way your language expresses “only" or “just". (If either is an affix or clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language express these concepts as separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, they are all separate words
Some are separate words, but others attach to another word
No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase

radioGroup.prompt: Where do these positive special degree elements that are not separate words (especially ‘all’) attach within the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: As a phrasal proclitic which attaches to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase
As a phrasal enclitic which attaches to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase

Some forms are phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase and others are phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase
As a prefix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
As a suffix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
Some forms are prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase and some forms are suffixes

form.prompt: Now key examples of the positive wordswords and affixes clitics meaning ‘all’, ‘almost’ and ‘only’ or ‘just’ included in full nominal phrases here:

radioGroup.prompt: Looking at the data in the box above, where do the special degree elements which are written as separate words occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Before it
After it
On either side, but not both sides at the same time
On either side, or both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the special degree words appear on either side of the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction
No, there are separate sets for each side

form.introduction: Now let’s consider the negative meaning ‘not’ when it modifies a nominal phrase. Note that not can occur in place of or before these other special degree words, as in the following English examples:
form.prompt: Be sure to distinguish elements like not which may negate a fully modified nominal phrase from words like no (to be treated on the next page) which take the place of any articles, demonstratives and possessors in the phrase.

Key the way your language expresses “not" (when it modifies a nominal rather than a verbal phrase), with each word on a separate line. (If “not" is an affix or a clitic which attaches to another word in the nominal phrase, key it here with a hyphen indicating which side it attaches on.)

radioGroup.prompt: Does your language express the negative meaning ‘not’ as one or more separate words which modify the whole nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, they are all separate words
Some are separate words, but some forms of ‘not’ attach to another word
No, they all attach to another word in the nominal phrase
There does not seem to be a way to express ‘not’ as modifying the whole nominal phrase in the language

radioGroup.prompt: Where do the negative special degree elements attach within the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: As a phrasal proclitic which attaches to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase
As a phrasal enclitic which attaches to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase

Some forms are phrasal proclitics which attach to the front of whatever word begins the nominal phrase and others are phrasal enclitics which attach to the end of whatever word ends the nominal phrase
As a prefix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
As a suffix which attaches to the head noun of the nominal phrase
Some forms are prefixes which attach to the head noun of the nominal phrase and some forms are suffixes

form.prompt: Now key examples such as (1) above of the negative wordswords and affixes clitics meaning ‘not’ included in full nominal phrases (without the positive special degree elements) here:

radioGroup.prompt: Looking at the data in the box above, where do the negative special degree elements which are written as separate words occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Before it
After it
On either side, but not both sides at the same time
On either side, or both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

radioGroup.prompt: Can all the special degree words meaning ‘not’ appear on either side of the rest of the nominal phrase?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, there is no restriction (or only one word that can appear either place)
No, there are separate sets for each side

radioGroup.prompt: Can the negative special degree elements meaning ‘not’ co-occur with the positive special degree elements, as in examples (2-4) above?
radioGroup.radio: Yes
No

form.prompt: Key your examples of the negative special degree elements meaning ‘not’ in full nominal phrases including the positive special degree elements here:

radioGroup.prompt: Where does the word or words meaning ‘not’ occur with respect to the rest of the nominal phrase (including the other special degree word(s)?
radioGroup.radio: Before it
After it
On either side, but not both sides at the same time
On either side, or both sides at the same time
Before it, or on both sides at the same time
After it, or on both sides at the same time
Only on both sides at the same time

form.prompt:
These negative elements will be discussed further in
Negative Constructions.
form.instruction:
In the lexicon, mark the words meaning all, not, almost, only, and just with the features makeDeg modifies_NP. Note that this is two separate features with a space between them. The first will change their syntactic category to Deg and the second adds the feature to distinguish them as the type that modifies NPs. If your language has a phrase meaning almost, such as not quite or just about, you need to make a single entry for these phrases with an underscore (_) between them and run the Join Compound program before AMPLE. These entries need the same features as a single word entry with a similar meaning would have.
Also, mark the word or words meaning all with the features plural quantifier

In the lexicon, mark the words meaning not with the features makeDeg modifies_NP. Note that this is two separate features with a space between them. The first will change their syntactic category to Deg and the second adds the feature to distinguish them as the type that modifies NPs.
Also, mark the word or words meaning not with the feature negative.
In the lexicon, mark the positive proclitic(s) meaning all with the features plural quantifier_prefix.
In the lexicon, mark the positive enclitic(s) meaning all with the features plural quantifier_suffix.
In the lexicon, mark the positive proclitics meaning all with the features plural quantifier_prefix and the positive enclitic(s) meaning all with the features plural quantifier_suffix.
In the lexicon, mark the positive prefix(es) meaning all with the feature plural.
In the lexicon, mark the positive suffix(es) meaning all with the feature plural.
In the lexicon, mark the positive prefix(es) and suffix(es) meaning all with the feature plural.
In the lexicon, mark the negative proclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_prefix.
In the lexicon, mark the negative enclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_suffix.
In the lexicon, mark the negative proclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_prefix and the negative enclitic(s) meaning not with the feature negative_suffix.
In the lexicon, mark the negative prefix(es) meaning not with the feature negative.
In the lexicon, mark the negative suffix(es) meaning not with the feature negative.
In the lexicon, mark the negative prefix(es) and suffix(es) meaning not with the feature negative.

In the lexicon, mark those special degree words which can only occur initially with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any special degree words which can occur on either side.

In the lexicon, mark the special degree words meaning not which can only occur initially with the feature DP-initial and those which can only occur finally with the feature DP-final. Do not enter either feature on any special degree words which can occur on either side.
